Award.AwardTitle: New Approaches for Better Spatial Frequency Localization in Two- and Three-Dimensional Data Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project concerns mathematical and algorithmic developments for image analysis (image compression, and the like). To compress or analyze images, it is useful to decompose them into elementary building blocks that are especially effective - in other words, it pays to use mathematical decomposition tools that achieve high accuracy with relatively few coefficients. For instance, in the transition from the JPEG standard to JPEG2000, the wavelet transform replaced the discrete cosine transform because it provided a sparser representation for images and because its performance degrades more gracefully when bandwidth is variable. This project aims to develop methods for improved sparse representation of images.

Curvelets and shearlets constitute a variant on the wavelet approach that can be shown, mathematically, to lead to even sparser representations for images. So far, they have not lived up to this promise in practice -- the only implementations in existence have a high overhead and a large redundancy factor. The Principal Investigator and her collaborators have identified several approaches that they expect will provide better basis constructions, which in turn will give better implementations, with great potential for applications. These will be developed in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Title: New Approaches for Better Spatial Frequency Localization in Two- and Three-Dimensional Data Analysis
PI: Ingrid Daubechies
Awardee: Duke University
Award Number: 1516988

Project Outcomes:

Wavelets and similar mathematical constructions are essential tools in image
analysis and image compression. The wavelet bases typically used in image
compression (e.g. in the JPEG2000 standard) do not have very good angular resolution.
The graduate student funded by this grant and the PI constructed alternative
wavelet bases that have better angular resolution; the limitations to their
spatial localization could be remedied at the cost of introducing a limited
redundancy. Both the bases and the redundant frames are linked to a multiresolution approximation hierarchy, allowing for fast implementation algorithms. In addition, the construction can be paired with a 2-dimensional generalization of the 1D splitting lemma proved earlier by the PI, making it possible to refine the angular resolution for finer-scale wavelet layers, resulting in a trade-off between angular resolution and spatial scaling similar to that present in curvelets or shearlets.

In addition, the PI and her student, together with other collaborators, worked on
constructions of specialized bases that combined spatial wavelets with non-local manifold learning techniques, with results that were comparable (at the time of their construction, 4 years ago) with those achievable by the state-of-the-art at the time. (They have since been surpassed by other techniques.)
